contentrichtext.text: {{Geobox | Settlement <!-- *** Heading *** --> | name = Zlaté Hory | other_name = | category = Town <!-- *** Image *** --> | image = Zlate hory.jpg|thumb|280px|View of the town from Biskupia Kopa mountain, Poland | image_caption = <!-- *** Symbols *** --> | flag = Zlaté Hory vlajka.svg | symbol = Zlaté Hory znak.jpg <!-- *** Name *** --> | etymology = | official_name = | motto = | nickname = <!-- *** Country etc. *** --> | country = Czech Republic | country_flag = 1 | state = | region = | region_type = | district = | district_type = | commune = | municipality = <!-- *** Family *** --> | part = | river = <!-- *** Locations *** --> | location = | elevation = | lat_d = | lat_m = | lat_s = | lat_NS = | long_d = | long_m = | long_s = | long_EW = | highest = | highest_elevation = | highest_lat_d = | highest_long_d = | lowest = | lowest_elevation = | lowest_lat_d = | lowest_long_d = <!-- *** Dimensions *** --> | area = 85.94 | area_round = <!-- *** Population *** --> | population = 4028 | population_date = 1.1.2012 | population_density = auto <!-- *** History & management *** --> | established = | established_type = | mayor = <!-- *** Codes *** --> | timezone = [[Central European Time|CET]] | utc_offset = +1 | timezone_DST = [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] | utc_offset_DST = +2 | postal_code = | area_code = | code = <!-- *** Free frields *** --> | free = <!-- *** Maps *** --> | map = Czechia - outline map.svg | map_background = Czechia - background map.png | map_caption = | map_locator = <!-- *** Websites *** --> | commons = | statistics = | website = <!-- *** Footnotes *** --> | footnotes = }} '''Zlaté Hory''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈzlatɛː ˈɦorɪ}}; until 1948 '''Cukmantl''', {{lang-de|Zuckmantel}}) is a town in the [[Jeseník District]], [[Olomouc Region]], [[Czech Republic]], on the border with [[Poland]]. It has a population of 4,447 (2006). The town was founded in 1224. Administrative parts: [[Rejvíz]], [[Horní a Dolní Údolí]] and [[Ondřejovice]] According to the [[Austria-Hungary|Austrian]] census of 1910 the town had 4,520 inhabitants, 4,341 of whom had permanent residence there. Census asked people for their native language, 4,341 (100%) were German-speaking. Most populous religious group were [[Roman Catholics]] with 4,441 (98.3%).<ref>Ludwig Patryn (ed): ''[http://www.sbc.org.pl/dlibra/docmetadata?id=11734 Die Ergebnisse der Volkszählung vom 31. Dezember 1910 in Schlesien]'', Troppau 1912.</ref> {{commons category|Zlaté Hory}} == Places of interest == * the main square with listed buildings * the church of the Ascension of [[Virgin Mary]] * the chapel of [[Saint Roch]] * [[Edelštejn]], [[Leuchtenštejn]] a [[Kobrštejn]] - ruins of the castles * the church of Virgin Mary, the Helpful * [[Biskupská kupa]] with a view-tower of [[Franz Josef of Austria|Franz Josef]] == Famous personalities == The German WWII panzer ace [[Kurt Knispel]] was born in nearby Salisfeld (Salisov). Knispel was the highest scoring tank ace of World War II with a total of 168 confirmed tank kills. ==International relations== {{See also|List of twin towns and sister cities in the Czech Republic}} ===Twin towns — Sister cities=== Zlaté Hory is [[town twinning|twinned]] with: * {{flagicon|POL}} [[Kętrzyn]], [[Poland]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{cs icon}} [http://www.zlatehory.cz/ Official website] * [http://www.rozhlednabiskupskakupa.cz/ view-tower] {{Jeseník District}} {{coord|50|15|17|N|17|23|38|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zlate Hory}} [[Category:Cities and towns in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Jeseník District]] [[Category:Cities in Silesia]] {{Olomouc-geo-stub}}
